hints.label: def-entropy-production-functional
hints.title: Entropy Production Functional
hints.content:
1661: :label: def-entropy-production-functional
1662: 
1663: The **entropy production** along a path $\gamma \in \mathcal{P}$ is defined as:
1664: 
1665: $$
1666: \Sigma[\gamma] := S_{\text{OM}}[\gamma] = \frac{1}{4\gamma T}\int_0^T \left\| \dot{v}_t + \nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x_t) + \gamma v_t \right\|^2 dt
1667: $$
1668: 
1669: This can be written in terms of the **entropy production rate**:
1670: 
1671: $$
1672: \Sigma[\gamma] = \int_0^T \sigma_t dt
1673: $$
1674: 
1675: where:
1676: 
1677: $$
1678: \sigma_t := \frac{1}{4\gamma T} \left\| \dot{v}_t + \nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x_t) + \gamma v_t \right\|^2 = L_{\text{OM}}(x_t, v_t, \dot{v}_t)
1679: $$
1680: 
1681: is the Onsager-Machlup Lagrangian density.
1682: 
1683: **Non-Negativity:**
1684: 
1685: $\Sigma[\gamma] \geq 0$ always, with equality if and only if $\gamma$ is a deterministic trajectory satisfying $\dot{v}_t + \nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x_t) + \gamma v_t = 0$.
1686: 
1687: **Physical Interpretation:**
1688: 
1689: The entropy production $\Sigma[\gamma]$ measures the irreversibility of the path. It equals the logarithm of the ratio of forward to reverse path probabilities (Crooks relation, {prf:ref}`thm-crooks-fluctuation-theorem`).
1690: 
1691: :::{note}
1692: **Alignment with Standard Literature:** This definition follows the convention of Sekimoto (2010) and Seifert (2012), where the entropy production is identified directly with the Onsager-Machlup action. Some earlier sources use $\Sigma = 2 S_{\text{OM}}$, but the modern consensus equates them. This ensures:

hints.label: thm-entropy-production-path-probability
hints.title: Entropy Production and Path Probability
hints.content:
1699: :label: thm-entropy-production-path-probability
1700: 
1701: The path measure {prf:ref}`def-path-measure` can be written as:
1702: 
1703: $$
1704: \frac{d\mathbb{P}_{\text{path}}[\gamma]}{d\mathcal{W}} = \exp\left(-\Sigma[\gamma]\right) = \exp\left(-S_{\text{OM}}[\gamma]\right)
1705: $$
1706: 
1707: where $\mathcal{W}$ is the Wiener measure.
1708: 
1709: **Interpretation:**
1710: 
1711: Paths with **high entropy production** are exponentially suppressed. The most probable paths minimize irreversibility.
1712: 
1713: **Connection to Detailed Balance:**

hints.label: def-work-heat-functionals
hints.title: Work and Heat Functionals (Autonomous Systems)
hints.content:
1721: :label: def-work-heat-functionals
1722: 
1723: For a path $\gamma \in \mathcal{P}$ in a system with **time-independent potential** $U(x)$, define:
1724: 
1725: **1. Conservative Work (Potential Energy Change):**
1726: 
1727: $$
1728: W_{\text{cons}}[\gamma] := \int_0^T F(x_t) \cdot v_t \, dt = -\int_0^T \nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x_t) \cdot v_t \, dt = U_{\text{eff}}(x_0) - U_{\text{eff}}(x_T)
1729: $$
1730: 
1731: This is the work done **by** the conservative force along the path.
1732: 
1733: **2. Heat Dissipated:**
1734: 
1735: $$
1736: Q[\gamma] := \int_0^T \gamma \|v_t\|^2 dt
1737: $$
1738: 
1739: (Energy dissipated to the thermal bath via friction)
1740: 
1741: **3. Total Mechanical Energy Change:**
1742: 
1743: $$
1744: \Delta E[\gamma] = E[\gamma(T)] - E[\gamma(0)]
1745: $$
1746: 
1747: where $E(x, v) = \frac{1}{2}\|v\|^2 + U(x)$ is the mechanical energy (with $m=1$).
1748: 
1749: **First Law for Autonomous Paths:**
1750: 
1751: $$
1752: \Delta E[\gamma] = W_{\text{cons}}[\gamma] - Q[\gamma]
1753: $$
hints.raw_directive:

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-103
hints.title: Distinction from Non-Equilibrium Work
hints.content:
1757: 
1758: :::{prf:remark} Distinction from Non-Equilibrium Work
1759: **Important:** The "work" $W_{\text{cons}}$ defined above applies only to **autonomous systems** where the potential does not explicitly depend on time.
1760: 
1761: For **non-autonomous systems** (e.g., external protocols varying a control parameter $\lambda_t$), the relevant quantity for fluctuation theorems is the **protocol work** (defined in {prf:ref}`thm-jarzynski-langevin-rigorous`):
1762: 
1763: $$
1764: W_{\text{protocol}}[\gamma] := \int_0^T \frac{\partial U(x_t, \lambda_t)}{\partial \lambda_t} \dot{\lambda}_t dt
1765: $$
1766: 
1767: This measures the work done **on** the system by varying the external parameter.
1768: 
1769: **Relationship:** For a protocol that changes the potential from $U(x, 0)$ to $U(x, 1)$, we have:
1770: 
1771: $$
1772: W_{\text{protocol}}[\gamma] = U(x_T, 1) - U(x_0, 0) - W_{\text{cons}}[\gamma]
1773: $$
hints.raw_directive:

hints.title: Stochastic Work Distribution
hints.content:
1777: 
1778: :::{prf:remark} Stochastic Work Distribution
1779: The work is **path-dependent** and **fluctuates** between realizations. The work distribution is:
1780: 
1781: $$
1782: P(W) = \int_{\mathcal{P}} \delta(W - W[\gamma]) \, d\mathbb{P}_{\text{path}}[\gamma]
1783: $$

hints.label: def-nonequilibrium-free-energy
hints.title: Non-Equilibrium Helmholtz Free Energy
hints.content:
1791: :label: def-nonequilibrium-free-energy
1792: 
1793: For a **time-dependent distribution** $\rho_t(x, v)$ (not necessarily QSD), define the **instantaneous Helmholtz free energy**:
1794: 
1795: $$
1796: F_t := \int_{\mathcal{M}} \rho_t(x, v) \left[U(x) + \frac{1}{2}\|v\|^2\right] d\mu + T S_t
1797: $$
1798: 
1799: where:
1800: 
1801: $$
1802: S_t := -\int_{\mathcal{M}} \rho_t \log \rho_t \, d\mu
1803: $$
1804: 
1805: is the **Gibbs entropy** (note: not entropy production!).
1806: 
1807: **Path-Dependent Free Energy:**
1808: 
1809: For a specific path $\gamma$, the "free energy cost" is:
1810: 
1811: $$
1812: \Delta F[\gamma] := F(\gamma(T)) - F(\gamma(0))
1813: $$
1814: 
1815: where $F(x, v) = U(x) + \frac{1}{2}m\|v\|^2 - T S_{\text{local}}(x, v)$ is a local free energy density.
1816: 
1817: **Challenge:**

hints.label: thm-jarzynski-equality
hints.title: Jarzynski Equality for Fragile Gas
hints.content:
1827: :label: thm-jarzynski-equality
1828: 
1829: Consider a **time-dependent protocol** where the confining potential is varied: $U(x) \to U(x, \lambda_t)$ with $\lambda_0 = 0$, $\lambda_T = 1$. Let $\Delta F_{\text{eq}} = F_{\text{eq}}(\lambda=1) - F_{\text{eq}}(\lambda=0)$ be the equilibrium free energy difference.
1830: 
1831: Then:
1832: 
1833: $$
1834: \left\langle e^{-W[\gamma] / T} \right\rangle_{\text{paths}} = e^{-\Delta F_{\text{eq}} / T}
1835: $$
1836: 
1837: where the average is over all paths $\gamma$ starting from the equilibrium distribution at $\lambda = 0$.
1838: 
1839: **Consequence:**
1840: 
1841: The free energy difference can be computed from **non-equilibrium work measurements**:
1842: 
1843: $$
1844: \Delta F_{\text{eq}} = -T \log \left\langle e^{-W / T} \right\rangle
1845: $$
hints.raw_directive:
1824: One of the most profound results in non-equilibrium thermodynamics is the **Jarzynski equality**, which relates the work distribution to free energy differences.
1825: 
1826: :::{prf:theorem} Jarzynski Equality for Fragile Gas
1827: :label: thm-jarzynski-equality
1828: 
1829: Consider a **time-dependent protocol** where the confining potential is varied: $U(x) \to U(x, \lambda_t)$ with $\lambda_0 = 0$, $\lambda_T = 1$. Let $\Delta F_{\text{eq}} = F_{\text{eq}}(\lambda=1) - F_{\text{eq}}(\lambda=0)$ be the equilibrium free energy difference.
1830: 
1831: Then:
1832: 
1833: $$
1834: \left\langle e^{-W[\gamma] / T} \right\rangle_{\text{paths}} = e^{-\Delta F_{\text{eq}} / T}
1835: $$
1836: 
1837: where the average is over all paths $\gamma$ starting from the equilibrium distribution at $\lambda = 0$.
1838: 
1839: **Consequence:**
1840: 
1841: The free energy difference can be computed from **non-equilibrium work measurements**:
1842: 
1843: $$
1844: \Delta F_{\text{eq}} = -T \log \left\langle e^{-W / T} \right\rangle
1845: $$

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-195
hints.title: (Sketch - See Appendix A for rigorous derivation)
hints.content:
1850: :::{prf:proof} (Sketch - See Appendix A for rigorous derivation)
1851: 
1852: The Jarzynski equality for underdamped Langevin dynamics is highly technical and requires careful treatment of protocol work, time-reversal symmetry, and kinetic energy accounting.
1853: 
1854: **Key Conceptual Steps:**
1855: 
1856: 1. **Work Definition:** For time-dependent potential $U(x, \lambda_t)$ with protocol $\lambda: [0,\tau] \to [0,1]$, the **protocol work** is:
1857: 
1858: $$
1859: W[\gamma] = \int_0^\tau \frac{\partial U(x_t, \lambda_t)}{\partial \lambda} \frac{d\lambda}{dt} dt
1860: $$
1861: 
1862: This is NOT simply the mechanical energy change $\Delta H[\gamma]$, which includes both protocol work and heat dissipation.
1863: 
1864: 2. **Crooks Relation:** Time-reversal symmetry of the underlying dynamics gives the fluctuation theorem:
1865: 
1866: $$
1867: \frac{P_F[W]}{P_R[-W]} = e^{(W - \Delta F_{\text{eq}})/T}
1868: $$
1869: 
1870: where $P_F[W]$ is the forward work distribution and $P_R[-W]$ is the time-reversed (backward) work distribution.
1871: 
1872: 3. **Jarzynski Equality:** Integrating the Crooks relation over all work values and using normalization $\int P_R[-W] d(-W) = 1$:
1873: 
1874: $$
1875: \left\langle e^{-W/T} \right\rangle_F = \int e^{-W/T} P_F[W] dW = \int e^{-\Delta F_{\text{eq}}/T} P_R[-W] d(-W) = e^{-\Delta F_{\text{eq}}/T}
1876: $$
1877: 
1878: **Critical Technical Issues** (see Appendix A {prf:ref}`thm-jarzynski-langevin-rigorous`):
1879: - Underdamped dynamics require careful boundary term accounting from kinetic energy contributions
1880: - The Onsager-Machlup action transforms non-trivially under time-reversal $t \to \tau - t$, $v \to -v$
1881: - Initial and final Boltzmann factors must be included correctly

hints.label: thm-crooks-fluctuation-theorem
hints.title: Crooks Fluctuation Theorem
hints.content:
1889: :label: thm-crooks-fluctuation-theorem
1890: 
1891: Let $P_F(W)$ be the work distribution for a **forward protocol** ($\lambda: 0 \to 1$) and $P_R(W)$ the work distribution for the **reverse protocol** ($\lambda: 1 \to 0$). Then:
1892: 
1893: $$
1894: \frac{P_F(W)}{P_R(-W)} = e^{(W - \Delta F)/T}
1895: $$
1896: 
1897: **Consequences:**
1898: 
1899: 1. Setting $W = \Delta F$ gives $P_F(\Delta F) = P_R(-\Delta F)$ (detailed fluctuation theorem)
1900: 2. Integrating recovers Jarzynski equality
1901: 3. Violations of the second law ($W < 0$) are possible but exponentially suppressed
1902: 
1903: **Interpretation:**
